close_symbols: struct dirent (full definition, including d_name member)
OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET (macro/inline that produces impl from table and token)
os_dirent_t (definition, including FileName member and its size)
explanation:
To decide whether any pointer in OS_DirRead_Impl should be const-qualified, the analyzer must know the exact types and function signatures involved so it can determine which pointers are only read-from (and therefore could be const) and which must remain mutable. Reason for each symbol:

- struct dirent (full definition, including d_name member): shows the type and mutability of d_name and whether accessing de->d_name is a read-only operation. It also confirms whether struct dirent contains any mutable state that would prevent declaring 'de' as a pointer-to-const.

- readdir (prototype): specifies the return type (struct dirent *) and parameter types (DIR *). Knowing this clarifies whether assigning the result to a const struct dirent * is allowed/appropriate and whether readdir requires a non-const DIR *.

- DIR (typedef/definition): required because readdir takes a DIR *; this lets the analyzer confirm the type of impl->dp and whether it must be non-const when passed to readdir.

- OS_impl_dir_internal_record_t (definition, including member dp): shows the type of impl->dp (likely DIR *) and whether impl is otherwise modified in this function. If impl is only read, impl could be declared as a pointer-to-const; if impl->dp must be passed as non-const to readdir, it constrains constness.

- OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET (macro/inline that produces impl from table and token): the macro expansion may affect the effective type/constness of impl and whether any implicit casts or modifications occur; the analyzer must see the macro to know if impl can safely be const-qualified locally.

- os_dirent_t (definition, including FileName member and its size): shows that dirent->FileName is written to in this function (so dirent cannot be const) and confirms size used with strncpy. This rules out making the dirent pointer const.

- OS_object_token_t (definition): used as the function parameter type (const OS_object_token_t *token). Knowing its definition verifies whether the const qualification on the token parameter is appropriate and if the macro/lookup dereferences or modifies the token in a way that would require it to be non-const.

- strncpy (prototype): shows parameter const-qualification (char *dest, const char *src, size_t n). This confirms that passing de->d_name (possibly non-const) to strncpy is compatible and that de->d_name only needs to be read, supporting a case for making 'de' a pointer-to-const.

These symbols give the necessary type and signature information to determine which local and parameter pointers in OS_DirRead_Impl are only read from (and thus candidates for const qualification) and which must remain mutable (because they are written to or passed to APIs requiring non-const).
